Answer: Although the most common transducer is the moving coil-permanent magnet transducer (the one on the image below), many variations of acoustic transducers already exist. Even a “Full Digital” speaker.The Moving Coil permanent magnet uses ferromagnetic or rare earth permanent magnets with high coercivity (resistance to loss of magnetism).There is the Field Coil TranAlthough the most common transducer is the moving coil-permanent magnet transducer (the one on the image below), many variations of acoustic transducers already exist. Even a “Full Digital” speaker.The Moving Coil permanent magnet uses ferromagnetic or rare earth permanent magnets with high coercivity (resistance to loss of magnetism).There is the Field Coil Transducer [ http://www.glowinthedarkaudio.com/speakers.html ] ( electrodynamic loudspeaker). In this one an electro magnet is energized by current through a second pair of connections to the driver.There is the surround-less driver [ http://www.fertinacoustics.com/ ]. As the name suggest this speaker has no surround at the end of the cone.There is the planar magnetic transducer electrostatic [ http://www.soundlab-speakers.com/ ]. The frequency response of a planar driver is not constrained by its mechanical design or construction. The light mass of the diaphragm allows it to reproduce the full audio spectrum as it responds very quickly to fast transient sounds... Imagine several drivers grouped together, because the total area of all the drivers combine and behave as one large and very fast speaker. In contrast to the conventional round drivers, the flat two-dimensional shape of planar drivers project sound in a more "natural" dispersion pattern almost like a beam of light instead of the sound radiating out in concentric rings rippling out from a central point as it happens with the conventional cone speaker.You have the concentric loudspeaker Cabasse  [ http://www.cabasse.com/en/ ]calls its version of the coincident source the Spatial Coherent Source, or SCS. This is the same as 3 separate fixed magnet speakers into one (woofer/mid range/tweeter).Another variation of a 2 way concentric speaker has been used by Tannoy [ http://tannoy.com/residential/#!series_118 ] for many years (Woofer/Tweeter).You have the Manger [ http://www.manger-audio.co.uk/manger-speakers.htm ]'s MSW full range driver that has a flat diaphragm which is bent to produce sound waves, rather than pushed and pulled like a regular "rigid" speaker cone.You have the drivers German Physics [ http://www.german-physiks.com/ ] uses. An omnidirectional speaker that radiates the wave from the sides of the cone rather than using the front of the cone to radiate the wave.You also have the MBL  [ http://www.mbl.de/?lang=en ]Driver "Radialstrahler" In this one several membranes compress and extend in order to create the sound wave.You have the ESS amt-1b Heil Air-Motion-Transformer (AMT) a type of electroacoustic transducer or loudspeaker, also called Air Velocity Transformer (AVT) or JET transducer. Invented by Dr. Oskar Heil. In contrast to a planar ribbon loudspeaker, the diaphragm of the AMT is a pleated shape similar to a bellows. The AMT moves air in an augmented, semi-perpendicular motion using a folded sheet (made of polyethylene, polyester or polyimide), structured around a series of aluminum struts positioned in a high-intensity magnetic field.You have the Ribbon [ https://www.madisoundspeakerstore.com/ribbon-tweeters/ ] and planar magnetic loudspeakers which consist of a thin metal-film ribbon suspended in a magnetic field. The electrical signal is applied to the ribbon, which moves with it to create sound waves. The advantage of a ribbon driver is that the ribbon has very little mass; thus, it can accelerate very quickly, yielding very good high-frequency response. Above and below the ends of the more or less rectangular ribbon, there is less audible output due to phase cancellation, but the precise amount of directivity depends on ribbon length.Planar magnetic Loudspeakers with ribbon and planar-magnetic drivers and a transmission line wooferYou have the Plasma driver [ http://www.lansche-audio.com/english/loudspeakers/plasma-tweeter/ ]. It has no moving parts. It varies air pressure via a high-energy electrical plasma instead of a solid diaphragm.The Eminent Technology TRW17 [ http://www.eminent-tech.com/RWbrochure.htm ] Rotary Subwoofer, the only subwoofer to be able to respond from 1Hz – 30Hz+/- 4dB. As it rotates its blades move to help it produce variations in the pressure wave.You have directional parabolic loudspeaker [ http://www.meyersound.com/product/sb-1/ ]s. The image is self-explanatory.You have the HyperSound Loudspeaker Technology [ http://hypersound.com/hypersound_technology.php ]You have horn and waveguide speakers like these Omni Audio [ http://www.omniaudio.com.au/ ]You have surface transducers, with these, you can turn a solid resonant surface into a "loudspeaker" or will convert virtually anything into a "sound source [ http://www.mkmdisplay.pl/en/intelligent-glass/products/soundpod-audio-transducer/ ]"You have some "variations" on this technology like the Greensound Technology Glass Speakers [ http://www.ult...

Answer: As of yesterday it’s no longer “next”.First pig heart being transplanted into a humanYesterday, January 10th, 2022, marks the first time an organ from a genetically modified animal, a pig, was transplanted into a human. We don’t know what will happen, but the pig was genetically modified in a way that makes it unlikely the organ will be rejected by the recepient and pig organs in general are quite similar to our own.I hope the recipient lives a rich full life with his new heart of a pig. Even if not, this is still a major step forward towards generating organs to order, without fear of rejectiAs of yesterday it’s no longer “next”.First pig heart being transplanted into a humanYesterday, January 10th, 2022, marks the first time an organ from a genetically modified animal, a pig, was transplanted into a human. We don’t know what will happen, but the pig was genetically modified in a way that makes it unlikely the organ will be rejected by the recepient and pig organs in general are quite similar to our own.I hope the recipient lives a rich full life with his new heart of a pig. Even if not, this is still a major step forward towards generating organs to order, without fear of rejection. Even if the heart is rejected and the donor dies, what we learn from the process will enable us to succeed the next time. I reckon this will become the mainstream way we get spare parts by the end of the decade in an optimistic scenario, by the end of the next decade in the pessimistic one.Either way, the moment is as groundbreaking as December 3rd, 1967, when the first human heart ever was transplanted, ushering the era of organ transplants of today. That patient died after 18 days, I hope this guy does better.

Answer: Next? When was the last one?While we have seen a resurrection of the use of planar magnetic and AMT tweeters, these technologies are are over forty years old and the vast majority of speakers, including the most advanced models, still use cones and domes.While material advances and design and measuring techniques have evolved over the years, most successful speakers are not much different conceptually than they were long ago.If we qualify a breakthrough as an advanced concept that changes the way most speakers operate, it may be too far off to think about.

Answer: Transfer learning in ML models.Humans are really good at generalizing. We only have to see a few dogs before we can recognize a dog when we see one.Machines are not. ML models require millions of examples before forming a reliable classifier, and that classifier is very specific to the data on which it was trained. If your training data doesn't include dogs with three legs, the model won't recognize them. A machine that plays Go is useless at checkers.Transfer learning is the ability to apply a model from one domain to a different one. It's hypothesized that the reason humans learn so quicklyTransfer learning in ML models.Humans are really good at generalizing. We only have to see a few dogs before we can recognize a dog when we see one.Machines are not. ML models require millions of examples before forming a reliable classifier, and that classifier is very specific to the data on which it was trained. If your training data doesn't include dogs with three legs, the model won't recognize them. A machine that plays Go is useless at checkers.Transfer learning is the ability to apply a model from one domain to a different one. It's hypothesized that the reason humans learn so quickly is that we are fitting new examples into our existing knowledge rather than forming entirely new categories. If we could teach machines to do the same, they would learn exponentially faster and apply that learning more effectively.Transfer learning is a very hot topic in AI research right now, so I expect major breakthroughs in the next few years. I think this may be sufficient to achieve artificial general intelligence, but even if not, it will dramatically extend the range of tasks that machines can accomplish.

Answer: The “let’s get away from a failing super-state” trope is a favorite of the leave campaign.However it is the largest trading bloc in the world - for it to “fail” would require some very significant problems. A Greek exit would be bad but an Italian one would severely damage the EU economically. However the Bloc would still survive unless there was a move to create a “two-tier” EU of the “Northern” nations. This would be almost impossible under the current EU.The only thing that could destroy the EU would be a return to populist politics throughout the community leading to actual conflict.FortunThe “let’s get away from a failing super-state” trope is a favorite of the leave campaign.However it is the largest trading bloc in the world - for it to “fail” would require some very significant problems. A Greek exit would be bad but an Italian one would severely damage the EU economically. However the Bloc would still survive unless there was a move to create a “two-tier” EU of the “Northern” nations. This would be almost impossible under the current EU.The only thing that could destroy the EU would be a return to populist politics throughout the community leading to actual conflict.Fortunately the EU is watching the UK self-immolate as it resorts to unfounded jingoism and characterisation of the EU as an “evil empire EU-USSR”. That’s putting off anyone else from going down that particular path at the moment (although there are political parties in Europe that lean in that direction).So the answer is almost certainly “no”; although there is always a risk, as the Brexit and Trump phenomena have shown, that democracy is extremely vulnerable to manipulation by social media.
